title: why is this game so prone to win or lose streaks?
body:
this isnt just a matter of attitude or tilt. this shit happens even if you go into every new game with a clear head.

its like for 5 to 10 games you get competent teammates, and then suddenly for the next couple of games you get a bunch of potatoes who are incapable of finding their own dick if they want to take a piss. then another day suddenly its the opposite again.

shouldnt this work exactly the opposite way? youd think when your mmr increases you get matched with and against teams that also have mmr comparable to yours.

but it feels like you suddenly get intentionally matched with people far below your own skill level. why is this happening? are you matching people with high mmr in the same division with people with low mmr to compensate to reach a mean value or something?

this might work mathematically, but causes the most frustrating games you could imagine. nobody involved is having fun.


id really like to see a source where i can see the mmr of myself, my team, and the enemy team. i just want to know if this is my own imagination, or actually how matchmaking works.

i repeat, im making a difference here between someone playing how to be expected for the level of play youre at and losing his lane, and an opponent snowballing and someone playing like absolute garbage as if he doesnt know how this game even works.

originally i thought something weird changes about matchmaking in promos that causes you to get matched with terrible people. but the longer i played, the more i realized why. because this is a general pattern in matchmaking in this game, and reaching promos are usually a result of a longer winstreak. so its more likely that the switch flips during, or just after the promos. but its happening outside promos aswell, simply after a longer winsteak. and then the entire streak of terrible players is replaced by a streak of good players on your team.

You have a very incorrect set of expectations of a random variable X that supposedly represents some score of performance in lane.

Let's just assume X is a single parameter variable. But it's not IID. It can't. If someone has an exp/gold/position advantage _before_ that influences the probability _now_. So if you have a "hit" then you not only get a value returned but also an increased chance of another hit. It's not going to ever be 100%, but the more you get, the more skewed towards you it is.

But then if the probability of a hit is always changing and also skewed towards favoring the previous outcome, then what you get in the expected behavior is extreme volatility OR a straight slope to victory depending on how much the parameter changes based on the previous outcome.

Why am I getting into the nitty gritty of this theoretical distribution that represents the probability of a win for a given side with given history in that game? Because I think you're judging your teammate's play with the expectations that if they were at least competent, then it would remain even and/or go back and forth tit for tat.

That isn't remotely the norm. Your streak of "terrible" players are almost certainly just players your skill level and their exhibiting behavior that is mathematically expected but doesn't meet your expectations of an average player is why you are thereby labelling them as terrible in the first place.

Why does this always happen in your promos? Because you only notice it in your promos. That and because the enemy is slightly skewed in their favor so that if you win your promos, the system is confident that you actually belong there. The slight skew makes the game harder and thus more likely to be volatile or a complete stomp for the enemy.

Winning in league of legends is like 50% luck. The MMR/Elo system that League uses was designed for 1v1 competitions. In a 1v1 situation you can control EVERYTHING in a fair environment. You lost? It's your fault. You had control over every single aspect of the game. You did not get paired with some idiot on your team. It is you and you only.

It's not the same in League. You can stuffed with 4 other players. You have no control over who they are besides that they're in your ELO range. Sometimes you will get idiots, sometimes you will get really good players. Sometimes your teammates decide to AFK/troll/pick shitty comps/etc. Sometimes the enemy team will do so.

I'm trying to say that luck is a big factor in these games. I am not saying skill is not there, however. Your individual play also factors in greatly toward a game. Sometimes, you play well, but it's not enough to carry your teammates. Sometimes you play like shit, but your teammates are good enough to carry you.

I just want to say that losing does really suck. Especially if you were carrying. I personally think that someone that's Silver 2 should only have to play at a Silver 1 level to deserve a win, or a Plat 3 player only has to play at a Plat 2 level to deserve a win. But that's just not how it works in this game. :(

Just don't take it hard if you lose. The fact that CHALLENGER smurfs, lose games in lower elos. Just remember that you can't win them all.

Complete truth. 
Because of the way these matches are made, wins and losses are based on chance. Having skill only increases your chances of winning.

The phenomenon works both ways actually, when you're on a huge losing streak, you tend to get matched with better and better teammates who are more likely to carry you. 

 I think the exact problem is that the MMR system in league isn't looking to match you with equal skilled players, it's looking to force you into a 50% win rate, which means when you're above that golden 50% win rate, it continues to match you with worse and worse teammates in an attempt to artificially bring your win rate down, and when you're below 50% win rate, it tries to artificially bring your win rate up by matching you with teammates who are statistically better players than you. 

No matter what the real logic involved in the MMR system is though, it's clearly broken and needs to be fixed about... 5 seasons ago.  A few matches ago, I had a Gold 1, a Plat 5 and three gold 3's, vs... a team of Plat 5's to Plat 3's.  Our Ashe proceeded to try and 2 v 1 Annie and Tristana under their tower at level 1 and blamed Braum for not saving her, and our top lane picked a champion he admitted he knew countered himself and demanded the jungle baby sit him to compensate.  I never see players like that when my win rate drops below 50%, that's for sure.

Let's take a look at your match history and see whether it's right or not. I will consider 4 games won/lost in a row a 'streak'. I will look at every game AFTER your streak. If you are right that's when the effect should kick in.

So your first winstreak was 5 days ago. It broke in your Lulu game.
Your team elo: plat 5, plat 3, gold 2, plat 4 and gold1 (you) vs plat 5, gold 1, plat 5, plat 5 and gold 1.

Your toplane won according to damage dealt and farm but probably lost due to the pressure of her team losing.
Your mid won HARD and tried to carry the game.
Your jungle lost hard
And the reason why you lost the game is that you lost Lulu + Draven vs Braum + Vayne.
But while Draven still managed to get a halfdecent KDA you place less wards then Braum, cleared less wards and had a smaller kill participation. You also died a lot which may be due to the fact that you built Rabadons while losing the game. 

So your lane losing actually lost the game even though the average elo of your team was higher than the average elo of the enemy team.
Your experience is rather subjective, but if you'd take an objective look at your games you'd realize that it's very often not your teams fault that you lose and certainly not Riots.
I took a look at a lot of games that broke your winstreakes - the elo of both teams was incredibly even.
Whoah, can I get you to analyze my games? That was hella thorough, I bet you could figure out what I need to do to improve :D

It definitely does not try forcing a 50% winrate, I have gone on massive win streaks before without having goofy team mates, or brain dead enemies. It's a lot about perspective, you start seeing team mates in a shady light when you are losing, You might win a few games and subconsciously await for it to break putting you on a minor tilt without knowing it.

Truth be told we have thousands of possible factors for win streaks and losses, and I don't think Riot has any control over it.

There was something a guy commented on another thread mentioned that's actually pretty true. If you're being matched up against people who are higher ranked than you are, then either you're on their rank in terms of mmr... or they're worse than their rank's mmr. 

My last ranked game was up against Diamonds and high Plats, while my team only had Plats. I also saw that my team's Tristana was 9W/25L, and thought "Welp. We work with what we got."

...Everybody but their mid-laner was bad. Because of that, everybody but our mid-laner got fed and we rushed the enemy team down through rapidly widening gold gaps. 

Point is, rank differences aren't always everything.

I think it has something to do with the system sees you winning. Then puts you in bad situations to see if you can still carry. If you can carry those games then it starts boosting you up faster.

Or it could be a conspiracy to keep a manageable number of players from getting higher rank and the system is a lie and the LCS is staged like WWE.

Judging from your post, it appears you omitted a key aspect in Riot's flawed MMR system: how does it know you are improving?
If two teams with similar MMR fight each other, the game should mathematically be equivalent to a coin toss.

If you win, that could just mean you got lucky. However, if you start winning a lot, that could suggest you are improving.
To prove that you are improving, the game essentially needs to put you in harder situations, either by making your team worse or the enemy team better, and test if you can still win or not.
If your skill level is around where your MMR is at, you won't. But if your skill level increased above your MMR, you will win, and your MMR will then be adjusted.

This works in reverse as well, so if you begin losing, you will be placed in less difficult situations. Of course, after that you will start winning again, putting the cycle back in place.
